destination.label: Montpellier
destination.title: Montpellier, or the sweet, Mediterranean life

content.intro:
Bright and friendly, Montpellier lives to the rhythm of its markets, its terraces, and the ‘Midi accent' of its inhabitants.

Montpellier is a quintessential southern city, a little piece of Occitanie caressed by light breezes redolent with sea scents and scrubland heated by the sun. It is a city of contrasts: proud of its thousand-year history and entrenched in a palpable living memory at every turn of the medieval streets that cross it, it nonetheless also looks to the future. Christian Lacroix has coloured its tramway and Jean Nouvel and Philippe Starck have helped to redesign its architecture. It thus seems to hesitate between heritage and modernity...
For the visitor, there is another, less weighty dilemma to consider: Which way to go? Should I head to the nearby sea with its untamed, scenic beaches and lively resorts, not to mention the salt ponds and pools of the Camargue, with its wild horses and wondrous wildlife? Or should I head into the hills, which are never far away, to the sunny slopes of the Languedoc and Pic Saint-Loup vineyards, proudly standing sentinel?
Not a dilemma at all really, but a question of balance and unity. Montpellier is indeed a city of fusions, like its Antigone district, which is a modern reinterpretation of an ancient heritage. Or its gastronomy, which combines like no other the products of the earth with those of the sea in highly innovative ways.
Life is easy in the shade of the plane trees that line the Place de la Canourgue or the 'circulades' of the historic Écusson district, lulled by the murmur of the city's 100 fountains and the accent of its inhabitants, animated by the joyous Arceaux market bazaar. Let yourself be won over by the spirit of the city, which is free, passionate, and friendly. Festive also, with the youthful support of its student population and the delicious local wines that would raise the lowest spirits. Carpe diem!

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Montpellier and Perpignan

seoData.seoTitle: Montpellier, or the sweet, Mediterranean life – Montpellier Travel Guide

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Montpellier

content.title: Baudon de Mauny: an 18th century gem

introduction.small: Treat yourself to an enchanted moment in this haven of peace, surrounded by a wonderful show of design through the ages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Baudon de Mauny: an 18th century gem

paragraphs.text:
Staying in this 18th-century house is a fabulous experience in the here and now set against a background of ageless elegance: a journey through time in a matter of seconds. Located in the heart of the old town, close to the Fabre Museum, this successful marriage between a boutique hotel and guesthouse lets you leave the urban bustle behind. This former National Heritage mansion offers eight unique rooms, including two suites, featuring contemporary design and high-quality services.

The service is commensurate with the atmosphere of the place: exceptional and reassuringly stalwart. Children are welcome, and a babysitting service is available.

Breakfasts are a true delight, comprised of fresh ingredients only and served in the winter garden. Wi-Fi has not been forgotten and flat screens are installed in each room. Comfort and grace combine to provide the luxury of a retreat from the world.

Baudon de Mauny
1 rue de la Carbonnerie
34000 Montpellier

+ 33 (0)4 67 02 21 77

http://baudondemauny.com/en/home-page

Rooms: from 145 EUR

content.title: Villa Duflot, re-energise in a Catalan house

introduction.small: South of Perpignan, in the new Arcades district, the Villa Duflot steers away from urban bustle in favour of calm voluptuousness in a luxurious house at the heart of nature.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa Duflot, re-energise in a Catalan house

paragraphs.text:
With its terracotta facades and Catalan architecture, the Villa Duflot exudes local authenticity. Amid a park filled with olive, palm and orange trees and eucalyptus, this four-star hotel seems cut off from the rest of the world. So much so that you may just want to stay in, enjoy the swimming pool, the surrounding nature, the gorgeous sundrenched terrace at the door of your bedroom, as well as the gastronomic restaurant and the various works of art scattered around the establishment (Art Deco furniture, sculptures, paintings…). Every detail, from the garden to the rooms, calls for creativity and artistic genius. In that respect, the villa regularly houses temporary exhibitions and organises private viewings.

Bikes are available for athletic excursions, but the Villa Duflot is first and foremost a gem of relaxation and well-being. Amid the greenery, the spa takes the cake with a hammam, a sauna and deckchairs arranged in the patio. This high-end accommodation has been labelled "Châteaux et Hôtels Collection", the mark of a real must-go-to destination where you will re-energise under the Mediterranean heat.

Villa Duflot
Avenue Charles Deperet
Rond-Point Albert Donnezan
66000 Perpignan

+33 (0)4 68 56 67 67

https://www.villa-duflot.com/en/

Rooms: from 139 EUR

content.title: Le restaurant Jean, Catalan cooking under a greenhouse

introduction.small: Its bistro cuisine with a Catalan twist and bodega spirit make Le Restaurant Jean a popular spot.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le restaurant Jean, Catalan cooking under a greenhouse

paragraphs.text:
The Jean from the restaurant's name is actually Jean-Baptiste Ciriani, owner of this establishment by the Perpignan train station. This former cooperage furnished with second-hand items and a lovely staircase conceived by designer Roger Talon is reminiscent of Catalan bodegas, replete with overloaded kitsch decoration. Dishes are also firmly etched in local traditions, offering colourful and flavourful bistro cuisine: cod fish in aioli au gratin, cargolade (grilled escargots, a must-try of Catalan gastronomy), duck breast skewers and calamari a la planxa, all to be enjoyed in the patio, when weather permits!

Closely associated with Perpignan, the address is a must for regulars who gather as soon as the sun rears its head. Le Restaurant Jean, with its welcoming and laidback atmosphere, dons coloured string lights at night. In summertime, behind the ancient iron gate, under the patio's greenhouse, you will be taken back the village folk dances of yesteryear. Catalan tapas keep coming, the place is packed… and yet service always remains fast and efficient – which is always handy considered the nearby station – as the staff greets you with an ever-smiling face. However, reservations are strongly recommended!

Le Restaurant Jean
1 rue de la Tonnellerie
66000 Perpignan

+33 (0)4 68 88 27 52

https://www.facebook.com/pages/category/French-Restaurant/Restaurant-Jean-Perpignan

Menu: around 18.50 EUR

content.title: Nyx, the goddess of night watches over you

introduction.small: Halfway between the station and the heart of the city, this stylish boutique hotel is ideally located for exploring Perpignan on foot.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nyx, the goddess of night watches over you

paragraphs.text:
The first thing that strikes at the Nyx boutique hotel is how ideally located it is to gleefully explore the city. Choose one of the 17 chic and refined rooms, stylishly furnished in a retro look, inspired by the goddess of dreams of the same name in Greek mythology. For instance, the "Balcony" rooms reveal various designs linked to night themes (grey, black and red tones), day themes (white and blue), the sun (gold and beige) and the moon (grey and white). Pull the curtains of your picture window, unveiling the balcony overlooking the heart of Perpignan with scenic views. The charming atmosphere is at once elegant and functional, lulling you into a feeling of great intimacy. If you are sensitive to noise - which could be the one downside to central urban accommodations - you simply need to ask for one of the courtside rooms. Families are not forgotten: a Nyx Family suite awaits them with a full-floor 4-bedroom apartment, which will come in handy when big brotherhoods reunite.

Nyx Hotel
62 bis avenue du Général de Gaulle
66000 Perpignan

+33 (0)4 68 34 87 48

www.nyxhotel.fr

Rooms: from 86 EUR

content.title: La Famille, locavore bistro with no fuzz

introduction.small: Near the Place des Poilus in Perpignan, La Famille restaurant takes you on a journey with its retro bistro looks and a menu based on local savoir-faire.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Famille, locavore bistro with no fuzz

paragraphs.text:
The first thing that springs to mind at La Famille restaurant in Perpignan is actually a smell. Delicious scents delicately permeate the air of the bistro to excite your senses. As soon as you walk in, other impressions take over: the retro decoration harks back to family houses, with old and slightly run-down concrete tiles, lush vegetation and small touch of kitsch elements to make the whole place somehow transgressive. Your ears will also be anticipating every small noise coming from the open kitchen, from delicate cooking sounds to uncorked bottles and glasses being filled to clink in harmony. Note that La Famille offers in that regard a wonderful wine selection.

Once you settle on your schoolboy chair, your sense of taste will take over; octopus, truffled mash, brine and velvet crab stew, prawns, fregola sarda, cranberry beans, thick slice of stone bass, turnips and broccoli and butter foam… Here, the trend is to eat locavore and, quite often, organic food. Indulge and enjoy.

La Famille
3 bis rue François-Marie Voltaire
66000 Perpignan

+33 (0)4 48 89 13 29

https://www.facebook.com/lafamillerestau/

Menu: around 31 EUR

content.title: Empanadas Club, Argentina in your plate

introduction.small: A speciality from South America, empanadas are small filled pastries available in a wide range of flavours. Try them while enjoying an Argentinian cantina atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Empanadas Club, Argentina in your plate

paragraphs.text:
With high tables tightly put together and various frames revealing Latin American vintage posters, the cantina atmosphere reigns supreme at Empanadas Club. As the name suggests, empanadas are kings here. These small filled turnarounds are crispy outside and melting inside, entirely homemade and on demand. Select your filling for two, three, even four empanadas and blend Latin American gastronomy with Mediterranean flavours, as you find yourself in the south of France. Choose the Choriqueso (with mildly spiced grilled chorizo, sundried tomatoes and melting cheese), the Verdura (flavourful vegetarian recipe with seasonal veggies in yellow curry), the Humita (corn-based with pre-Colombian onions and typical Argentinian herbs), or why not try the Sorpresa del Mes, the filling of which changes monthly, depending on seasonal products and the chef's whim. Very successful, the restaurant is often packed and reservations are recommended.

Empanadas Club
15 rue de Ratte
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 83 43 28 23

www.empanadasclub.com

Menu: 3.50 EUR per empanada

content.title: Art takes centre stage at Hyacinthe Rigaud Museum

introduction.small: The history of Catalan and French Perpignan unfolds on the canvases of the Hyacinthe Rigaud Museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Art takes centre stage at Hyacinthe Rigaud Museum

paragraphs.text:
Since 1833, Hyacinthe Rigaud Museum, in Perpignan - a less than two-hour drive from Montpellier - exhibits pictorial works inspired by the wealth of the region. Capital of the Kingdom of Mallorca before being annexed by France, the city of Perpignan is torn between its Catalan past and French present.

Painters such as Aristide Maillol, Étienne Terrus and Miquel Alcanyís, and of course Rigaud, transcribed the history of this contrasted city on their canvases. The three permanent collections display Gothic, Baroque and modern works, while two temporary exhibitions are organized each year, in summer and autumn.

After major works to extend and modernize the building,. today the site combines two historic private mansions - Lazerme's and Mailly's - to form a 1,400 sqm exhibition space. Young visitors (age 18 months to 4) are not forgotten, giving them and their parents an opportunity to attend introductions to art and history.

Hyacinthe Rigaud Art Museum
21 rue Mailly
66000 Perpignan

+33 (0)4 68 66 19 83

https://www.musee-rigaud.fr

content.title: Palace of the Kings of Majorca, Perpignan's gem

introduction.small: Explore the Palace of the Kings of Majorca and its history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palace of the Kings of Majorca, Perpignan's gem

paragraphs.text:
The heart of the city of Perpignan houses a palace. Built in the 13th century by the King of Majorca, it was the centre of the short-lived Majorca kingdom (1276-1344) amid the city, when Perpignan was still considered the economic, political and cultural heart of Medieval Mediterranean. At the start of the construction, it was still using a late Roman-style architecture, but slowly evolved after 1300 to finally showcase its Gothic nature. It became a citadel in the 16th century when French and Spanish engineers built the surrounding fortress walls.

Admire the impressive towers, including the high one used as the entrance and starting point of the visit, but also the Holy Cross chapel, adorned with a pink and blue marble door. The royal residence has also retained painted decors and is worth a look. From there, the view spreads out all the way to the Canigou mountain. You will undoubtedly be under the spell of the palace's splendour. Note that some animations take place all year long, in addition to the guided or free tours.

Palais des rois de Majorque
Rue des Archers
66000 Perpignan

+33 (0)4 68 34 96 26

https://www.perpignantourisme.com/en/decouvrir/voir-faire/monuments/palais-rois-majorque

content.title: The Botanical Garden: lush greenery in the city centre

introduction.small: Like an open-air museum, the Montpellier Botanical Garden holds many treasures and curiosities that are sure to amaze you.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Botanical Garden: lush greenery in the city centre

paragraphs.text:
Montpellier's Jardin des Plantes is the oldest botanical garden in France. It was created at the request of Henry IV in 1593 and originally dedicated to medicinal research, but is now listed as a Historic Site and Monument. The city's residents have made it their choice for strolling. Offer yourself a moment away from the urban bustle and step into this peaceful four-hectare theatre of greenery. The setting is as romantic as one could wish, with surprises and discoveries that dot the way.

Enjoy the beneficent shade of the majestic century-old ginkgo biloba tree, or walk along the paths planted with palms and other tropical species. For children, a walk in the Jardin des Plantes is an opportunity to become familiar with the current issues of biodiversity and sustainable development, with pedagogical and themed tours offered for this purpose. A most enjoyable way to 'cultivate one's garden'.

Jardin des Plantes de Montpellier
163 boulevard Henri IV
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 67 63 43 22

https://www.facebook.com/jdpmontpellier/

content.title: Place Jean Jaurès: the place to be

introduction.small: Much more than a prominent square in the urban configuration, it is an absolute must for the people of Montpellier, who gather there on all kinds of occasions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Place Jean Jaurès: the place to be

paragraphs.text:
The setting? A pretty square, bordered by Melia trees, where colourful umbrellas overlap in summer and terraces remain full all year long. The atmosphere? Joyous, free, warm and festive a fine description of the South of France in fact…

During the day, you can choose where you sit according to the orientation of the sun in order to read while drinking a coffee, or you can make a stop there to regain your strength after a hectic shopping spree in the adjoining streets of la Loge and l'Aiguillerie.

At night, Montpellier youth make this site and its popular cafés the starting point for many a night out. On game nights, be it rugby or football, you can sing along with the fans of the teams of your choice and make friends with the locals. Under the benevolent gaze of political idol and moral compass Jean Jaurès' statue, watching over close by.

Place Jean-Jaurès
Écusson district
34000 Montpellier

https://www.montpellier-france.com/offre/fiche/place-jean-jaures/PCULAR034V50LISY

content.title: Promenade du Peyrou: Montpellier all around

introduction.small: A highlight and one of the most emblematic places in Montpellier, exposed to the four winds.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Promenade du Peyrou: Montpellier all around

paragraphs.text:
An immediate impression of harmony overtakes you when you find yourself on the Peyrou Promenade, a three-hectare royal square created in the late 17th century by the architects Davillier, Giral, and Donnat. The harmonious proportions of its classical architecture; the unity of the triumphal arch, the water tower, and the aqueduct which constitute the axis and interact with each other; the overall balance of the composition to exalt the equestrian statue of Louis XIV, which marks the centre; and the linearity of the terraces linked to each other and connected by stone steps you must take to walk the length of the promenade all are outstanding.

One's second impression, as you walk along, is an incredible feeling of freedom created by this esplanade's construction. The stunning, unobstructed view takes in the rooftops of the city and the horizon, where one can make out the Pic Saint-Loup and, in clear weather, the Canigou, heralding the Pyrenees.

Perfect for a walk in the shade of plane trees, the Peyrou is also the ideal place for impromptu games of petanque, just before settling into the best seats in the house for a glorious sunset.

Promenade du Peyrou
Place Royale du Peyrou
34000 Montpellier

https://www.montpellier-france.com/offre/fiche/place-du-peyrou/PCULAR034V50VDYM

content.title: The Brasserie du Théâtre, tradition in an Art Deco universe

introduction.small: This key location, close to the theatre, immerses you in old-world luxury that you will not want to leave.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Brasserie du Théâtre, tradition in an Art Deco universe

paragraphs.text:
The Brasserie du Theatre is a Montpellier institution straight out of The Great Gatsby that will take you right back to the 1920s: the embodiment of Art Deco aesthetic and the ultimate era of refinement and celebration. Wood panelling, stained glass, mirrors, tulip lamps, and leather-upholstered banquettes create an elegant and intimate setting.

Whether you slide into a smooth tobacco-coloured leather armchair, or set up elbow to elbow with other guests at the zinc bar, your impression will always be that of living in a moment of suspended animation, defying the laws of passing time. The menu features a seafood platter that may lure you, given the promise, inscribed in gold letters on the front of the establishment, of a "daily arrival from Brittany". A range of dishes like seared scallops in fleur de sel and seasonal vegetable tarts, a tuna tataki with artichoke tempura or the grenadine of veal with a star anise jus, confit aubergine and potato rostis make your visit a real immersion in the tradition of home cooking and the "brasserie" culture.

La Brasserie du Théâtre
22 boulevard Victor-Hugo
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 67 58 88 80

www.brasseriedutheatre.fr

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: Opera Berlioz-Le Corum: a space like no other

introduction.small: Unmatched capacity and advanced facilities make this institution the pride of Montpellier.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Opera Berlioz-Le Corum: a space like no other

paragraphs.text:
Friendly and resolutely modern, Montpellier has naturally become a popular destination for organisers of cultural events, such as business tourism. It was therefore necessary to equip itself with infrastructures commensurate with its reputation. This has been accomplished with flair by Le Corum, a hybrid space in the city centre that offers 6,000 sqm of meeting space dedicated to conferences, exhibitions, and other professional events, and three auditoriums with superior acoustic qualities, homes for the Opera Berlioz and the Montpellier National Orchestra, all on a single site.

Whether you attend conferences on water, energy, or gastronomy or sit in on the Radio France Music Festival which is held there annually the extreme comfort and functionality of this upscale space will impress. If you are not attending a specific event, the panoramic roof will allow you to escape the chaos of the downtown core, while offering sweeping views of the Polygone and Écusson quarters.

And for food lovers, the Corum Brasserie's inventive cuisine will delight with its Provencal accents. A must, with something to please everyone.

Opéra Berlioz-Le Corum
Esplanade Charles-de-Gaulle
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 67 61 67 61

www.montpellier-events.com/en/The-Corum/Presentation

content.title: Place de la Canourgue: a garden of delights

introduction.small: One of the oldest and finest squares in the city reveals itself in the shade of nettle trees…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Place de la Canourgue: a garden of delights

paragraphs.text:
Place de la Canourgue has the effect of a dowager who has not aged a bit, fittingly draped in the memory of its former glory. The erstwhile centre of Montpellier in the 17th century, by the 19th century it was the most beautiful square in the city: a place where people went to stroll, and to see and be seen. It now seems to be dozing pleasantly in the shade of the celtis trees that line it.

Everything is delightful, starting with the alleys festooned with boxwood, the mansions, and the antique rose beds, whose perfumes are sure to make you dizzy. Take time to pause in one of the chic cafés and restaurants to enjoy the languor of the moment.

For lovers and dreamers, this place is undoubtedly the most romantic in the city, so take the opportunity for an intimate moment not far from the bustling city centre. Antique lovers, this is also the place for you, as the neighbourhood abounds in antique shops.

Place de la Canourgue
34000 Montpellier

https://www.montpellier-france.com/offre/fiche/place-de-la-canourgue-canourgue-square/PCULAR034V50LIUG

content.title: Saint Peter's Cathedral: witness to history

introduction.small: A sentinel erected in the heart of the Écusson quarter, it watches benignly over Montpellier life.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint Peter's Cathedral: witness to history

paragraphs.text:
In Montpellier as elsewhere in France, churches and cathedrals are at the heart of the city, silent refuges for those who venture there and a double reward, given the spectacle of art and history that plays out before our eyes.

This is also the case when, guided by the two majestic Gothic towers that constitute the porch, you enter St. Peter's Cathedral, consecrated in 1367 by Pope Urban V. The experience is moving and possibly a little intimidating in the monumentality of its architecture, a legacy of its defensive past and the terrible repercussion of religious wars.

Battlements and ramparts forge the singularity of the place, acting as guarantors for the memory of battles fought between Catholics and Protestants. Every moment of your presence in this sacred place makes you a witness to history as you discover the Romanesque nave, dominated by an almost celestial vault peaking at 28m, the 17th century gargoyles, the great 18th century organ and the Gothic choir… Right up until time sounds its accord every hour, completing your 'conversion' to the solemnity of the place, with the entire clarion of the Cathedral's bells ringing out.

Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Montpellier
1 rue Saint-Pierre
Quartier de l'Écusson
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 67 66 04 12

https://www.montpellier-france.com/offre/fiche/saint-pierre-cathedral/PCULAR034V50LN5I

content.title: The Petit Jardin Bistro: the charms of bistronomy

introduction.small: Dusting off classic French cuisine, bistronomy brought a breath of freedom and simplicity to bistro food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Petit Jardin Bistro: the charms of bistronomy

paragraphs.text:
Tired of convoluted and pretentious cuisine? Make your way to the Petit Jardin, and return to a simpler, more immediate, and especially more authentic cooking. The chef prepares frank bistro cuisine that is generous and delicious right before your eyes. And since nothing beats mixing genres, the sacrosanct French culinary tradition rubs shoulders here (without offending) with inspirations from elsewhere. This is normal after all, as we are in the south on the shores of the Mediterranean, at the crossroads of cultural influences.
You might therefore hesitate between a Black Angus tataki with sundried vegetables and mint cream, lamb kefta in vegetable tagine with chickpea cream, skate wing in nutty butter with creamy risotto or the rack of pork in mild spices served with red lentil and sundried tomato salad.
Indulgence and simplicity are both present in this well-known meeting place, which you may have trouble leaving, especially on a soft summer evening when you dine on the patio under century-old trees lit with lanterns.

Le Petit Jardin
20 rue Jean-Jacques Rousseau
Quartier de l'Écusson
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 67 60 78 78

www.petit-jardin.com

Menu: around 51 EUR

content.title: The Fabre Museum: a celebration of artistic creation

introduction.small: An exceptional museum with an international influence, housing more than 5,000 works.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Fabre Museum: a celebration of artistic creation

paragraphs.text:
The Fabre Museum stands out with exceptional exhibitions that are constantly renewed and ever popular. You will be delighted with its richness and the major works it contains. It is an important player in the French and European museum landscape, and a cultural highpoint in Montpellier, founded by local painter François-Xavier Fabre.

Rubens, David, Corot, Delacroix, Ingres, Cabanel, Courbet, Matisse, Delaunay, Stael, and Valadon right through to Pierre Soulages are on exhibition here. Accessible to all, their works are arranged in smartly designed themed tours, making it easy even for children, formalised by the museum's offerings of "family tours".

Take your time over elegant and enveloping rooms dedicated to 19th-century creations, immerse yourself in the Orientalism of Delacroix, and succumb to the beauty of his Women of Algiers. Over in the section on 20th century art, you will find the dizzying colour patterns in the brilliant canvases of Matisse and Delaunay almost irresistible, and get caught up in the ultimate nuance: the intriguing large black format works of Pierre Soulages presented in a new exhibition space of textured glass. Why wait? Get onboard this journey through artistic periods or pictorial art through its various means of expression.

Musée Fabre
39 boulevard Bonne Nouvelle
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 67 14 83 00

https://museefabre-en.montpellier3m.fr/

content.title: The Réserve Rimbaud: a starred getaway by the river

introduction.small: In the kitchen, real luxury sometimes comes from simplicity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Réserve Rimbaud: a starred getaway by the river

paragraphs.text:
There are obvious reasons for the good fortune of this place, as it is suspended between a mirror of water and an outdoor theatre of green. Certainly, the beauty of the setting is not its only source of success, but what a setting! It is every bit as remarkable as chef Charles Fontès' Michelin-starred cuisine.

You may succumb to vertigo, but it will not stem from the impression of levitation or the proximity of the moving waters of the Lez below the sun-drenched terrace, rather from the gustatory pleasure that will titillate your taste buds when you try the marinated sardines in tomato vinegar, oysters and caviar, octopus with basil or roasted turbot in fish stew juice, orange-flavoured fennel and a light rouille sauce. For dessert, let the strawberries in crispy shell, black pepper and olive oil surprise you. Whatever the chef feels like on any given day, he always favours simple and regional products that he loves to work with, transform, modify and yet never alter. A real sleight of hand.

La Réserve Rimbaud
820 avenue Saint-Maur
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 67 72 52 53

https://reserve-rimbaud.com/en/

Menus: 40 EUR (Lunch menu), 95 EUR (‘Celebrating The Past' set menu), and 110 EUR (Tasting menu)

content.title: Les Bains de Montpellier: a modish oasis in the heart of the city

introduction.small: A gourmet haven of calm and coolness, Les Bains is anchored in authenticity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Bains de Montpellier: a modish oasis in the heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
Since 1998, Guy Falco has brought new life to the former public baths of Montpellier, this heritage curiosity having been unfairly shunned until then. The grand and unusual setting does not in the least imply convoluted cooking. Cod aioli and lukewarm vegetables, veal breaded escalope with gorgonzola sauce and linguine or beef tartare with goat cheese are the result of a simple, fresh cuisine, where the product, without artifice, takes centre stage.

Seated on the incredible patio, you may imagine yourself in an oasis of freshness, with the canvas of the white parasols so big they look like a camp canopy, and the century old palm trees and the pond at its centre conferring Mediterranean cool. There is a different atmosphere inside, but it is just as appealing, with original exposed brick, oak floors, and velvet lining the seats. Ideal for a late or romantic dinner, the tone is cosy and refined in and out, so which will you choose?

Les Bains de Montpellier
6 rue Richelieu
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 67 60 70 87

les-bains-de-montpellier.com

Menu: around 30 EUR for lunch and 40 EUR for dinner

content.title: The Domaine de Verchant: serenity among the vineyards

introduction.small: This five-star hotel is the perfect place to enjoy a unique experience amidst the vineyards, awakening your taste buds while indulging yourself.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Domaine de Verchant: serenity among the vineyards

paragraphs.text:
Do you dream of a prestigious experience in the heart of a vineyard? The Domaine de Verchant invites you to enjoy a moment of excellence, combining luxury, refinement, and a complete change of scene. This 16th-century domain offers rooms and suites worthy of James Bond: some even have a round bed encircled by a veil that opens and closes with a very well thought out automation system. Each room has been devised to evoke a unique world, but it is the signature Italian design that unquestionably brings them all together. The bathroom lighting changes to suit your mood, while the Italian showers and an open-air Jacuzzi conspire to make you never want to leave your room.

Yet it is impossible to resist the call of the spa, with its Bizzaza mosaic-covered walls, aromatic shower, and massages overlooking the vineyards and indoor pool laziness and relaxation in the spirit of wellness. And if the sun is shining, lounging around the outdoor pool while sipping a fresh fruit juice is another option.
But your experience of the domain would not be complete without dinner at the gourmet restaurant, the Verchant, where chef Alexandre Caillaud masterminds an alchemy of Mediterranean flavours. One does not stay at the Domaine de Verchant, one lives!

Domaine de Verchant Hotel & Spa
1 boulevard Philippe Lamour
34170 Castelnau-le-Lez

+33 (0)4 67 07 26 00

https://www.domainedeverchant.com/en/luxury-hotel-montpellier

Rooms: from 229 EUR

content.title: The beaches: a variety of wild and manmade seaside attractions

introduction.small: Between the gentle curves of the dunes and the infinite horizon, enjoy the incredible space of freedom and the multiple distractions offered by the Montpellier coast.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The beaches: a variety of wild and manmade seaside attractions

paragraphs.text:
Do you prefer pebble or sandy beaches? Lazing or water sports? Scenic waterfront or developed beach resorts? Never mind if you are unable to decide, the Montpellier coastline the richest and most diverse in the Languedoc-Roussillon offers all that and more.

Invite your other half for a peaceful day at the natural wilderness beach of Aresquiers, a protected area, where you can choose between wearing a swimsuit and… getting an overall tan. At the stroke of noon, stroll over to La Voile Bleue for a tasty lunchtime break.

If you are with family and friends, the most popular and oft-visited beach is Palavas-Les-Flots, with its clubs and beach bars, beach volleyball, and other beach amenities. For thrill seekers, water sports and all forms of skiing are available to lend you wings: inflatables, jet skiing, parasailing, and especially kite surfing a clever combination of ride, traction and flight. And why not take advantage of some of the advanced courses at one of the many schools that line the beach?

La Voile Bleue
Avenue du Grand Travers
34280 La Grande-Motte

+33 (0)4 67 56 73 83

https://lavoilebleue.fr

content.title: Hôtel des Arceaux: one surprise after another

introduction.small: Sophisticated refinement, where contemporary design and classical architecture meet for your greater delight.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel des Arceaux: one surprise after another

paragraphs.text:
The elegant powder-toned stone facade of this 19th century mansion is punctuated by period ironwork resembling embroidered stripes on the front of a prom dress. But its contemporary and sleek interior is proof that a hotel of charm does not inevitably mean a four-poster bed and lion-paw bath.

Here you will find ultra-modern comfort, enhanced by immaculately stylish surroundings that you can enjoy throughout your stay including whirlpool and chromotherapy, air conditioning, LED screens, and comfortable bedding.

If the weather is mild (which is almost always the case in Montpellier), take the time to enjoy your breakfast in the delightfully lush and exotic walled garden. A moment of grace and quiet amidst palm trees and orchids before you head out to join the noisy crowd at the nearby Arceaux Market.

Hôtel des Arceaux
33-35 boulevard des Arceaux
34000 Montpellier

+33 (0)4 67 92 03 03

www.hoteldesarceaux.com/en/

Rooms: from 90 EUR

content.title: Hotel Les Templiers in Aigues-Mortes: stately calm, shady terrace

introduction.small: Charm and tranquillity are the watchwords of your stay here in the little town of Aigues-Mortes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Les Templiers in Aigues-Mortes: stately calm, shady terrace

paragraphs.text:
A few kilometres from Montpellier in Aigues-Mortes, you will find sanctuary in the old chalk-coloured stones and the protection of the thick walls of this three-star hotel located within the fortifications of the town. It keeps you cosy warm in winter and offers shady respite from the sweltering heat of summer. A former 18th-century merchant's house, it has been transformed by the owners into a comfy cocoon, decorated here and there with travel souvenirs and antique furniture, such as the old, slightly worn club chairs that you will find in most of the 12 rooms. The comfortable, bright, and spacious rooms will make you feel right at home.

The shaded patio and swimming pool, again in rough stone, invite you to relax and let go, while the ancient olive trees and slender cypresses make you forget the presence of the nearby city. The restaurant, too, mustn't be missed; feel free to succumb to its excellent wine list…

Hotel Les Templiers
23 rue de la République
30220 Aigues-Mortes

+33 (0)4 66 53 66 56

https://hotellestempliers.ellohaweb.com/en-GB/

Rooms: from 140 EUR

content.title: Domaine de Biar, to reconnect with nature

introduction.small: Rejuvenate and take time to contemplate what beauty the earth provides.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Domaine de Biar, to reconnect with nature

paragraphs.text:
Located a few kilometres from Montpellier, Domaine de Biar will delight nature lovers. A neglected 18th-century Montpellier folly (pleasure palace), Biar was resurrected in 2007 under the leadership of its new owner, who fell under its spell and decided to renovate it according to the rules of art.

What has been created is a true eco-lodge: all materials used come from organic construction, the domain is fully autonomous in its water management, and 20 horses have been bred on the land that encircles the domain.

Inside, the choice between the rooms, the suite, and the apartment, all beautifully refurbished, borders on agonising. Impeccable service truly does credit to the establishment's five stars. Breakfasts are prepared exclusively with products from organic farms and the Domaine's own vegetable garden. The surrounding trees, lush meadows, and horses roaming nearby offer a bucolic setting, offset by the luxurious azure-blue pool, plunging us into a sublime reverie. The Domaine de Biar is not so much a hotel as an experience.

Domaine de Biar
Chemin de Biar
34880 Lavérune

+33 (0)4 67 65 70 06

https://domainedebiar.com/biar/en/

Rooms: from 228 EUR

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Montpellier
content.introduction: Montpellier and Perpignan enjoy a typically Mediterranean climate. In Montpellier, temperatures are almost always pleasant and mild. The city boasts one of the highest number of days of sunshine per year in France. Rainstorms can occasionally be violent, causing flash floods in the area of the city cut through by the river Verdanson. Perpignan has a similar climate: winters are mild and summers are hot and dry, although the tramontana northerly wind sweeps through the city frequently during the summer, moderating temperatures somewhat.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in France is the Euro (EUR).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Montpellier and Perpignan International Airports
airports.description:
Montpellier Méditerranée Airport

The airport is located in Mauguio, about eight kilometres (five miles) southeast of the city centre.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Montpellier and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the D172 and D66.
    • One drop-off area (0 to 10 minutes for free) and three parking areas at the airport, for short, medium and long-term stays. From EUR 3.60 to EUR 6.10 for 1 hour, and EUR 15 for 1 day.
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall.
  • By shuttle bus
    • Bus line 620 connects the airport with Place de l'Europe. The trip takes about 25 minutes and the fare is EUR 1.60 each way. Buses to the city centre run every day between 8:30 a.m. and 11:15 p.m., and buses to the airport run from 5 a.m. to 8 p.m.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside the terminal. The trip to central Montpellier takes about 20-30 minutes and costs around EUR 25 (EUR 35 at night).
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)8 25 83 00 03 (EUR 0.12 EUR/minute + call cost)
  • Website: https://montpellier-airport.com/

Perpignan-Rivesaltes International Airport


The Perpignan-Rivesaltes International Airport serves the entire French administrative department of Pyrénées-Orientales. It is located about eight kilometres (three miles) north of Perpignan.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Perpignan and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the D5 local road or A9 motorway (La Catalane).
    • A parking facility with a total of 517 spaces is available (free for the first 15 minutes, EUR 3 for up to 1 hour, EUR 18 for 1 day, EUR 20 for 2 days and EUR 10 for each additional day).
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall.
  • By bus
    • Line 7 buses run every hour Monday to Saturday (7:10 a.m. to 10:30 p.m. from the airport and 5:55 a.m. to 7.25 p.m. from Perpignan city centre). Three buses run on Sunday and holidays. Travel time is around 20 minutes. A single ticket costs EUR 1.30 and a return ticket EUR 2.30.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside the terminal. The trip to central Perpignan costs around EUR 25 (EUR 35 at night).
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)4 68 52 60 70
  • Website: https://www.aeroport-perpignan.com/
  • Train + Air Service
  • Customers connecting to Paris (Charles de Gaulle) who have an Air France flight number must visit the Train + Air desk at the Montpellier Saint-Roch station between 24 hours and 20 minutes before departure: train tickets will be issued to them upon presentation of a valid airplane ticket.
  • You will find all necessary information on the website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/resainfovol/avion_train/reservation_avion_train_tgvair_airfrance.htm
  • The Montpellier Saint-Roch TGV station is located at place Auguste Gibert, 34011 Montpellier. It is open from 4:45 a.m. to 11:30 p.m. Monday to Friday, and 5:45 a.m. to 11:30 p.m. on Saturdays and Sundays. From the station, you can access:
    – Public transport: tramway (lines 1, 2, 3 and 4), Montpellier Airport shuttles (connections to tram lines 1 and 4), intercity buses and city buses (lines 6, 7, 8, 11 and 12).
    – Private transport: drop-off area, taxis, car hire companies, parking facilities, bike hire companies.

For all necessary information about the Train + Air desk, please visit https://www.garesetconnexions.sncf/fr/gare/frmpl/montpellier-saint-roch/services

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Montpellier
transportation.description:
Montpellier offers excellent public transport options. The city's buses and trams can get you almost anywhere, and run late into the evening. If your destination is not on the bus routes or tram lines, you can always take a taxi or walk. In fact, the city's entire historic centre, one of the largest in France, is a pedestrian zone.

Perpignan is a relatively compact city and most sights are within walking distance of each other. If desired, the city also has an efficient network of bus routes covering the entire metropolitan area.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Montpellier or Perpignan, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: Montpellier Tourist Office
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: 30 allée Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, 34000 Montpellier
  • Telephone: +33 (0)4 67 60 60 60
  • Website: https://www.montpellier-france.com/

information.title: Perpignan Tourist Office
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: Place de la Loge, 66000 Perpignan
  • Telephone: +33 (0)4 68 66 30 30
  • Website: https://www.perpignantourisme.com/en

information.title: French Travel Guide
information.description:
The official tourism website of France has plenty of information available on Montpellier and Perpignan.

  • Website: http://www.atout-france.fr/content/covid-19-1

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. The cities of Montpellier and Perpignan count several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to France. For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr/
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description: There are no specific food safety risks. French government authorities promote good hygiene practices and put in place strengthened control procedures for sites especially frequented by tourists during the summer months.

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Perpignan and Montpellier.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic French phrases that will make your stay in Montpellier or Perpignan a little easier:
phrases: I don't understand: Je ne comprends pas
What time is it?: Quelle heure est-il ?
How much is (…)?: Quel est le prix de (…) ?
Where can I find (…)?: Où puis-je trouver (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: Où puis-je acheter (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Montpellier
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Montpellier and Perpignan each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March or April: Easter Monday (national holiday)
May 1: Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8: Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: June 21: Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also celebrated internationally as World Music Day, for this festival many free concerts featuring all types of music are held in the streets and at various venues across both Montpellier and Perpignan.

events.title: July 14: Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Montpellier and Perpignan, festivities similar to those in all other French cities are organised: parades, concerts and fireworks displays.

events.title: August 15: Assumption Day (national holiday)
events.description: This celebration, still very popular in Montpellier and Perpignan, is marked by the faithful with religious processions and ceremonies through the streets.

events.title: Third weekend in September: European Heritage Days (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up numerous sites and monuments, many of which are normally closed to the public, such as castles and private collections. A great opportunity for a lovely stroll through the city to admire architectural treasures!

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: French citizens gather at war memorials to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Montpellier and Perpignan, with families and friends celebrating the new year.

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government Offices
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 12 p.m. and 1 p.m. to 4:30 p.m.

banks.title: Banks
banks.openingHours: Usually open Tuesday to Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 1:30 p.m. to 5 p.m. (12:30 p.m. on Saturdays)

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: last Sunday in March

End of daylight saving time: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Perpignan and Montpellier, like elsewhere in France, a service charge is always included in the bill. If you are particularly pleased with the service, you may certainly leave a few extra euros on the table. But this additional tip is neither expected nor necessary.
